body: here I added some payload lists for login bypasses, which I often use in the CTF and bug bounty world
Fix a typo in a tool link
Prefer ${IFS} to $IFS when doing filter bypass without space as $IFS does not work as a separator for certain commands.

Noticed that the repository does not have the clickjacking technique. Added a README.md file containing brief summary and methodologies for clickjacking technique in accordance with the contributing guidelines. 

I have added in exploit details along with some example codes
- UI Redressing
- Invisible Frame
- Button/Form Hijacking
- Execution Methods
- OnBeforeUnload Event
- XSS Filter
  - IE8 XSS filter
  - Chrome 4.0 XSSAuditor filter
 
Along with some preventive measures that can be implemented _(did not see this much in other directories and thought this would be a good addition)_

Added a small challenge as well.

This is a python script that exploits the latest vulnerability in Metabase which is an open-source project and gives you a reverse shell on your machine from server perspective.


Awaiting for positive response

## Description:
Changes are made to Web Cache Deception.

Added Vulnerability description.
Updated Exploit description.
Added demonstrative image for the exploit.
This commit add a Kerberoasting technique without domain account/credentials just a user without pre-authentication (AS_REP Roastable)
appropiate -> appropriate
Provided a reduced character example that only relies on = ' and ! not being filtered.

it can test in Sqli-labs Less-32,

Simple automatic shell upgrade via rustcat, that's based off commands from conptyshell, sets up the terminal to receive the reverse shell connection, then rustcat will spawn the TTY automatically.
Added Lodash on the SSTI chapter. All the payloads are tested during the down under ctf 2023.
I edited the shell by automating
Added `CloudFox` and `CloudFoxable` to the tools/training sections respectively.
Column names of the specified table can be more easily extracted in a better output. Tested during the CTF

This commit addresses an issue in the pattern matching logic where the character '>' was not properly matched with its URL entity encoding '>'. By extending the matching criteria, the code now correctly recognizes both representations.

From [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48958814/what-is-the-rust-equivalent-of-a-reverse-shell-script-written-in-python?answertab=active#tab-top). 

It works fine
Cognito Scanner is a CLI open-source tool. It enables to pentest Cognito AWS instance easily. It can be installed through a python package

Add JSON simple paylaod with autosubmit form. Using autosubmit form instead of AJax, allow to bypass some protection like the Standard Enhanced Tracking Protection in Firfefox, which will refuse to send cookie with  cross-site  Ajax request (tested with Firefox 115.0.2esr),.

Hello,

This is my contribution to your repo.

In fact, there are two errors in my opinion:
- You don't need sudo to use docker
- The docker image is no longer available ([see yourself](https://hub.docker.com/search?q=remnux%2Fmetasploit))

Like they say to use their installers, I propose not to use the docker image. <https://github.com/rapid7/metasploit-framework>

I'm not an expert on Metasploit, so feel free to ask questions.

It is possible to do persistence via Linux Package Managers like apt (Debian family) with unattended upgrades enabled.

I've tried to give a brief (and certainly not exhaustive) summary of what HTTP request smuggling actually is, HTTP/2 request smuggling attacks and James Kettle's new research on client-side desync attacks.

Hopefully this is a useful level of simplification; I'm happy to elaborate more or less if anyone has suggestions, or to close this completely if this isn't enough of a 'payload' to fit here (I figured it counts as the 'techniques' - but it seems like )

Linux evasion techniques were previously included as part of persistence, but the number of techniques are varied enough where it likely should be its own article.  (I'm planning to submit an additional PR after this to expand on the existing techniques and to include additional ones.  Adding them all to the persistence page would make it too bulky.)
Added an alternative to document.cookie for situations when this text is blacklisted.
Adding the WGET command and fixing errors in the summary part.

Nevertheless, I think that the trickest CVE repository is a really nice addition to quickly asses known CVE's for known PoC's since the list will be updated on a regular basis automatically.

This PR will add remote-method-guesser as tool. I also changed the overall structure of the previous article keeping most of the content but adjusting it to the layout mentioned in CONTRIBUTION.md

I thing rmg is a great addition to the landscape of RMI exploitation and definitely belongs to the article. Let me know if you have any objections or prefer other changes.

This will add [Trivy](https://github.com/aquasecurity/trivy) to the tools section of the topic `Api Key Leaks`. This is currently my go-to tool to scan docker images or repositories for secrets and therefore should be mentioned. As I could not see it mentioned somewhere, I picked this topic as it seemed to fit best. But it might also fit for other topics such as scanning for vulnerable dependencies (CVE) used in a projects or weaknesses in regards of SBOM/IaC. If you see a better fit for Trivy at other topics or might want to add it redundantly multiple times I guess we could add it to this MR.
Let me know what you think. :)

(Also changed the phrasing for two other tools as their main repository uses the upper/lowecase as changed which should not require a separate MR)

Hekatomb is a python script that connects to LDAP directory to retrieve all computers and users informations. Then it will download all DPAPI blob of all users from all computers. Finally, it will extract domain controller private key through RPC uses it to decrypt all credentials.

More infos here : https://github.com/Processus-Thief/HEKATOMB

## Change 
`https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_NoSQL_injection` to `https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/latest/4-Web_Application_Security_Testing/07-Input_Validation_Testing/05.6-Testing_for_NoSQL_Injection`

## Why
Click the `Testing for NoSQL injection - OWASP` link to move it to the SQL Injection item in OWASP. WSTG has the same NoSQL Injection document, so I changed it to that link.

~~I don't like that I had to use a small sleep, but I found directly mapping the stdin and stdout between the socket and the process, to be very unstable on Windows.~~

Switched to a thread based model, to save the sleep.

~~As a note force closing the connection on the remote causes python to not exit properly (happened with my previous implementation too), this means you will leave the remote IP and port in the process details.~~

Fixed closing on the remote.

To avoid error like this one:
```
git.exe clone --progress -v "https://github.com/swisskyrepo/PayloadsAllTheThings" "C:\tmp\PayloadsAllTheThings"
Cloning into 'C:\tmp\PayloadsAllTheThings'...
POST git-upload-pack (174 bytes)
POST git-upload-pack (412 bytes)
remote: Enumerating objects: 6028, done.
remote: Counting objects: 100% (583/583), done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (274/274), done.
remote: Total 6028 (delta 264), reused 524 (delta 243), pack-reused 5445
Receiving objects: 100% (6028/6028), 11.75 MiB | 3.90 MiB/s, done.
Resolving deltas: 100% (3420/3420), done.
error: invalid path 'Server Side Request Forgery/Images/Parser & Curl < 7.54.png'
fatal: unable to checkout working tree
warning: Clone succeeded, but checkout failed.
You can inspect what was checked out with 'git status'
and retry with 'git restore --source=HEAD :/'
```

For reference : Here is the complete list of special characters on Windows https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filename#Reserved_characters_and_words
Different filesystems will also have restricted characters.

The following line is not required but supposedly optimizes code.  However, this breaks on some Python 2 installations, where the future module version installed is > 0.16.  This can be a pain to revert.
```python
from builtins import range
```

Kali Linux is launched using VMware to become the platform launching SQLMAP

Use SQLMAP to exploit the database using SQL injection

Since we retrieve only the rows with a specific table name `name ='table_name', the table name won't start with `sqlite_` .
Thus, we can remove the unnecessary condition.

Before the `JWT token` was being **encoded/decoded** manually. The JWT's module does all that without manual decoding and splitting. 

This PR contains the code to encode the JWT token with type `None` while using `JWT's library` in python.

Cloudflare XSS Bypass via add 8 or more superfluous leading zeros for dec and 7 or more for hex.

Dec: `<svg onload=prompt%26%230000000040document.domain)>`
Hex: `<svg onload=prompt%26%23x000000028;document.domain)>`

And another bypass

`xss'"><iframe srcdoc='%26lt;script>;prompt`${document.domain}`%26lt;/script>'>`
